messages: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (00:57): hmm‚Ä¶ I notice weird artifacts in the W3C bugzilla home page

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:01): #query     { background: url(index/search.gif)  no-repeat; }
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (01:01): annevk: is Chaals still the Opera AC Rep?
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (01:03): will have to read how to change affiliation again for groups (for Monday)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:03): DataTransferItem is now specced
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:03): finally i can get to dropzone=""!
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:05): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: „Åä„ÇÅ„Åß„Å®„ÅÜ
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:05): or rather, gratul?°lok
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:06): thanks
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:06): I have a dream, that one day a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 will start speaking English
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:06): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: translate.google.com
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:06): wonders when drag and drop was first implemented
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:07): Oh, it's not that I don't understand, it's more of a comment on his polyglottitude
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:07): ok so now that we have a model to talk about, the dropzone="" syntax discussion is more interesting
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:08): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: How would you say "in meatspace" or "offline" or "in real life" in Japanese?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:08): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: cadw breuddwydio
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:08): welsh now eh
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:09): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Come on, "cadw" is so obvious
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:09): Welsh is so cool
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:09): people who get to speak Welsh every day are lucky
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:09): Icelandic too
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:10): offline is just katakanized
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:10): katakana-ized
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:10): obvious?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:10): i love that google translate can translate into latin now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:10): that's precious
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:11): yeah, the Latin thing is fun
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:11): I sweat it is used to do Esperanto as well
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:11): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: What other language would use cadw
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:11): *swear
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:11): I don't even have any idea how to pronounce "cadw"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:12): i pronounce it "keep"
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:13): Google translate doesn't quite manage the classic "catapultam habeo. nisi pecuniam omnem mihi dabis ad caput tuum saxum immane mittam."
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:13): hm
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:13): what to expose to dropzone=""
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:14): i guess first i should add a warning about type strings containing spaces
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:16): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: about your question, I guess „Ç™„É?„É©„Ç§„É?„Åò„ÇÉ„Å™„ÅÑÁîüÊ¥ª or „Ç™„É?„É©„Ç§„É?„Åò„ÇÉ„Å™„ÅÑ‰?ñÁïå
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:16): neither of which is terrifically poetic
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:17): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, what's dropzone?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:17): but that's the way I'd say it if I was actually trying to express it myself to somebody
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:17): lachy: the attribute we're adding to make it possible to declaratively do the ondragenter/ondragover part of the DND model
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:17): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: see http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=10712

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:18): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: drag and drop originally came from IE, right? Do you know how soon after it was that other browsers started to implement it? I mean, how long ago? 2005?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:19): no idea
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:19): webkit was first
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:19): maybe 2005?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:19): IE had it in IE4 or so
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:19): years ago
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:19): yeah, 2005 is what I was guessing for other browsers
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:20): 5 year lag between it being implemented across multiple browsers and it actually getting spec'ed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:20): well i first specced it in like 2006 or 2007 or so
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:20): i thought firefox implemented it after 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e specced it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:20): the new stuff i added recently isn't implemented anywhere
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:21): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: yeah, iirc that's right
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:21): in fact the new stuff was based on implementation feedback
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:21): opera doesn't support dnd yet
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:21): it's almost directly copied from something i think the chrome team first suggested in the whatwg list, which then had some feedback from various others
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:22): a few years back
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:23): oh i should make dropzone="" also let you say if it's a move, copy, or link
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:24): dropzone="copy text/plain text/html org.example.text file:text/plain file:text/html file:application/xhtml+xml"

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:25): which would mean that the cursor would be set to "copy" if any of the items in the drag data store had any of the given types, where the types refer to text items except if they start with "file:" in which case they're file types?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:27): or maybe dropzone="s:text/plain s:text/html f:text/plain f:text/html s:org.example.text copy" - each type has to start with f: or s: for files or strings, and there can be a "copy" keyword anywhere?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:28): yipes
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:28): that looks pretty complicated
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:28): error prone
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:29): are you serious about that?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:29): well in practice it'd usually just be dropzone="move s:text/plain"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:29): or dropzone="f:image/png f:image/jpeg"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:30): is that that bad?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:30): i dunno how else to do it really
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:31): i think we need a prefix just so that we have room in the lexical space to add features
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:31): I'm trying to think of some precedents
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:31): some other attributes with that kind of microsyntax
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:32): and honestly I'm also thinking about, That's gonna suck if I have to be the one to write the datatype checking for it in the validator
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:33): the validator really needs some additional contributors
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:33): especially ones that are happy to do all the time-consuming and unrewarding implementation parts
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:33): so I'm sure we're going to have a lot of people lining up for that job
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:34): it might even surpass the long line of editors we have waiting to write specs
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:35): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: anyway, looking at it objectively, I guess it ain't so bad
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:35): if it's going to be done declaratively
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:36): it's simpler than the JS equivalent, at least
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (01:37): dropzone="str(text/plain, text/html, org.example.text) file(text/plain, text/html) copy"
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (01:39): hmm not sure it is more readable.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:41): harder to parse, too
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:41): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:42): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: what does "link" do?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:42): like a symlink?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:42): goes to read the current spec
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:42): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:42): ah, OK
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:42): think url dragged to desktop
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:42): is that new-ish?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:42): nope
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:43): link, move, and copy were the three types IE supported from the start
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:43): man, I need to actually read this stuff
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:43): finds a bit he forgot to spec out
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:43): oops
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:43): or actually, remember it

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:46): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: this is probably a dumb thought, but I would think it'd be a lot less error-prone if it essentially used keywords instead of mime types
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:46): or commonly recognized extensions
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:46): well technically it's whatever the author uses
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:46): the spec doesn't require it to be a mime type
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:47): it only uses mime types for things from the OS
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:47): I see
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:47): since different OSes use different type mechanisms for the drag-and-drop and clipboard mechanisms, and mime types are the least crazy of them
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:47): that i have found
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:47): and we need a single common one to use on all platforms
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:47): for the web
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:50): notices slinkcoding is here
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:50): slinkcoding: hey, glad to see you here
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:51): guesses slinkcoding might either be sleeping or out doing something fun since it's Friday night at 00:45 in Budapest
